explanation: can_compress takes a pointer parameter 'con' and passes it unchanged to MHD_lookup_connection_value. To determine if can_compress itself violates the MISRA rule (i.e. modifies the parameter variable 'con'), we must inspect any callees or macros that might actually assign to or otherwise modify the parameter identifier within the body of can_compress. MHD_lookup_connection_value is called directly with 'con' and could be implemented as a macro, inline wrapper, or function that expands/delegates and (possibly) performs assignments to its argument name; therefore its definition is required to be sure no modification of the 'con' parameter identifier occurs. The static graph shows MHD_lookup_connection_value delegates to MHD_lookup_connection_value_n, so include that symbol as well in case the actual modification is performed there or the former is just a thin wrapper/macro. (Other functions used in can_compress such as strcmp, strstr, strlen do not receive 'con' and thus cannot modify the can_compress parameter; the struct definition of MHD_Connection is not required to determine whether the parameter variable itself is reassigned.)
